docs.title: Overview
docs.text: hashreport is a command-line tool that generates comprehensive hash reports for files within a directory. The reports can be output in CSV or JSON formats and include detailed information such as the file name, path, size, hash algorithm, hash value, and last modified date. Designed for speed and efficiency, hashreport can handle large volumes of files and offers filtering options to include or exclude files based on size, type, or name patterns.

docs.title: Quick Start
docs.text:
# Install hashreport
pip install hashreport

# Generate a hash report
hashreport scan /path/to/directory

See the Workflow Overview for a complete guide to using hashreport.

docs.title: Memory Management
docs.text:
Control memory usage through various settings:

# settings.toml
[hashreport]
# Resource monitoring settings
memory_threshold = 0.85  # % of total memory
mmap_threshold = 10485760  # 10MB - Use mmap for files larger than this
chunk_size = 4096  # bytes

docs.title: Thread Configuration
docs.text:
Optimize thread usage for your system:

# settings.toml
[hashreport]
# Thread pool settings
min_workers = 2
batch_size = 1000
max_retries = 3
retry_delay = 1.0
resource_check_interval = 1.0  # seconds

docs.title: Input Validation and Sanitization
docs.text: hashreport implements robust input validation and sanitization to ensure safe operation.

docs.title: Path Validation
docs.text:
• Absolute and relative paths are supported
  • Path traversal attempts are blocked
  • Special characters are properly escaped
  • Unicode paths are handled correctly

docs.title: Pattern Validation
docs.text:
• Glob patterns are validated for syntax
  • Regular expressions are checked for validity
  • Pattern length is limited to prevent DoS
  • Special characters are properly escaped

docs.title: Size Validation
docs.text:
• File size limits are enforced
  • Memory limits are respected
  • Buffer sizes are validated
  • Chunk sizes are checked

docs.title: Email Notifications
docs.text: hashreport can email reports upon completion using SMTP.

docs.title: Basic Email Setup
docs.text:
hashreport scan /path/to/directory \
  --email recipient@example.com \
  --smtp-host smtp.example.com \
  --smtp-user username \
  --smtp-password password

docs.title: Security Best Practices
docs.text:
1. Use Environment Variables 

    export HASHREPORT_SMTP_HOST=smtp.example.com
export HASHREPORT_SMTP_USER=username
export HASHREPORT_SMTP_PASSWORD=password

  2. Use App Passwords

  3. For Gmail, use App Passwords instead of account passwords

  4. Generate at: Google Account → Security → 2-Step Verification → App passwords

  5. Use TLS/SSL 

    hashreport scan /path/to/directory \
  --email recipient@example.com \
  --smtp-host smtp.example.com \
  --smtp-port 587 \
  --smtp-tls

  6. Secure Configuration File 

    # settings.toml
[hashreport.email_defaults]
port = 587
use_tls = true
host = "smtp.example.com"
timeout = 30
default_subject = "HashReport Results"
retry_attempts = 3

docs.title: Testing Email Configuration
docs.text:
Test your email settings without processing files:

hashreport scan /path/to/directory \
  --email recipient@example.com \
  --smtp-host smtp.example.com \
  --smtp-user username \
  --smtp-password password \
  --test-email

docs.title: Gmail Example
docs.text:
Using Gmail's SMTP server:

hashreport scan /path/to/directory \
  --email recipient@gmail.com \
  --smtp-host smtp.gmail.com \
  --smtp-port 587 \
  --smtp-user your.email@gmail.com \
  --smtp-password "your-app-password"

docs.title: Glob Patterns
docs.text:
Use glob patterns to match files:

# Match all PDF files
hashreport scan --include "*.pdf" /path/to/directory

# Match specific file types
hashreport scan --include "*.{jpg,png,gif}" /path/to/directory

# Exclude temporary files
hashreport scan --exclude "*.tmp" /path/to/directory

docs.title: Regular Expressions
docs.text:
Use regular expressions for more complex patterns:

# Match files with date in name
hashreport scan --regex --include ".*\d{8}.*" /path/to/directory

# Match specific file extensions
hashreport scan --regex \
  --include ".*\.(jpg|png)$" \
  --exclude "thumb.*\.jpg$" \
  /path/to/directory

docs.title: Filelist with Patterns
docs.text:
The filelist command supports the same pattern matching:

# List all PDF files
hashreport filelist --include "*.pdf" /path/to/directory

# List files with regex
hashreport filelist --regex --include ".*\d{8}.*" /path/to/directory

docs.title: Report Formats
docs.text:
hashreport supports multiple report formats:

# Generate CSV report (default)
hashreport scan -f csv /path/to/directory

# Generate JSON report
hashreport scan -f json /path/to/directory

# Generate both formats
hashreport scan -f csv -f json /path/to/directory

docs.title: Report Configuration
docs.text:
Configure report generation behavior:

# settings.toml
[hashreport.reports]
include_metadata = true
include_timing = true
max_concurrent_writes = 4
compression = false

docs.title: Custom Report Names
docs.text:
Control report filenames:

# Custom named reports
hashreport scan /path/to/directory -o custom_report.csv

# Multiple formats with custom names
hashreport scan /path/to/directory \
  -o report.csv \
  -f csv -f json

docs.title: Understanding Changes
docs.text:
The comparison functionality identifies several types of changes:

  • Modified: File exists in both reports but has different hash values
  • Moved: Same file (identical hash) exists in different locations
  • Added: File exists only in the newer report
  • Removed: File exists only in the older report
graph LR
    A[Old Report] --> D[Comparison Engine]
    B[New Report] --> D
    D --> E{Change Detection}
    E -->|Modified| F[Hash Changed]
    E -->|Moved| G[Location Changed]
    E -->|Added| H[New File]
    E -->|Removed| I[Deleted File]
    F --> J[Generate Report]
    G --> J
    H --> J
    I --> J
    J --> K[Output CSV]

docs.title: Output Format
docs.text:
Changes are displayed with bold text for better visibility:

  • Change type is displayed in bold
  • File paths show the original and new locations
  • Details include hash values and change descriptions
  • Complete path information is shown in separate columns

docs.title: Saving Comparisons
docs.text:
Comparison results can be saved to CSV format:

hashreport compare old_report.csv new_report.csv -o /path/to/output/

The output filename will be generated automatically using the format: compare_<old_report>_<new_report>.csv

docs.title: Using with Version Control
docs.text:
Example workflow for tracking file changes:

# Generate initial report
hashreport scan /path/to/project -o initial_report.csv

# Make changes to files
git add .
git commit -m "Update project files"

# Generate new report
hashreport scan /path/to/project -o new_report.csv

# Compare reports
hashreport compare initial_report.csv new_report.csv

docs.title: Quick Start
docs.text: Here are some common use cases to get you started quickly:

docs.title: 1. Basic Directory Scan
docs.text:
Generate a hash report for all files in a directory:

hashreport scan /path/to/directory

docs.title: 2. Scan with Specific Hash Algorithm
docs.text:
Use SHA-256 for better security:

hashreport scan --algorithm sha256 /path/to/directory

docs.title: 3. Filter by File Type
docs.text:
Scan only PDF files:

hashreport scan --include "*.pdf" /path/to/directory

docs.title: 4. Generate Multiple Formats
docs.text:
Create both CSV and JSON reports:

hashreport scan -f csv -f json /path/to/directory

docs.title: Command Structure
docs.text:
The basic command structure is:

hashreport scan [OPTIONS] DIRECTORY

docs.title: Scanning a Directory
docs.text:
To scan a directory and generate a hash report:

hashreport scan /path/to/directory

docs.title: Choosing Hash Algorithm
docs.text:
You can specify which hash algorithm to use:

hashreport scan --algorithm sha256 /path/to/directory

To see available hash algorithms:

hashreport algorithms

docs.title: Output Formats
docs.text:
hashreport supports CSV (default) and JSON output formats:

# Generate CSV report (default)
hashreport scan -f csv /path/to/directory

# Generate JSON report
hashreport scan -f json /path/to/directory

# Generate both formats
hashreport scan -f csv -f json /path/to/directory

docs.title: Specifying Output Location
docs.text:
Control where reports are saved:

hashreport scan /path/to/directory -o /path/to/output/

docs.title: Size Filters
docs.text:
Filter files by size:

# Files larger than 1MB
hashreport scan --min-size 1MB /path/to/directory

# Files smaller than 1GB
hashreport scan --max-size 1GB /path/to/directory

# Files between 1MB and 1GB
hashreport scan --min-size 1MB --max-size 1GB /path/to/directory

docs.title: Pattern Matching
docs.text:
Include or exclude files by pattern:

# Include only .txt files
hashreport scan --include "*.txt" /path/to/directory

# Exclude .tmp files
hashreport scan --exclude "*.tmp" /path/to/directory

# Use regex patterns
hashreport scan --regex --include ".*\.txt$" /path/to/directory

docs.title: Processing Control
docs.text:
Control how files are processed:

# Limit number of files
hashreport scan --limit 100 /path/to/directory

# Disable recursive scanning
hashreport scan --no-recursive /path/to/directory

docs.title: File Listing
docs.text:
Generate a list of files without calculating hashes:

hashreport filelist /path/to/directory

docs.title: Viewing Reports
docs.text:
View report contents in a paginated format:

# View entire report
hashreport view hashreport_<timestamp>.csv

# Filter report entries
hashreport view hashreport_<timestamp>.csv -f "mydoc"

docs.title: Comparing Reports
docs.text:
Compare two reports to identify changes:

# View differences between reports
hashreport compare old_report.csv new_report.csv

# Save comparison results
hashreport compare old_report.csv new_report.csv -o /path/to/output/

The comparison will show:

  • Modified files (hash changed)
  • Moved files (same hash, different location)
  • Added files (new in second report)
  • Removed files (missing in second report)

docs.title: Configuration Options
docs.text: hashreport uses a TOML configuration file to store user settings. The default location is ~/.config/hashreport/settings.toml.

docs.title: Core Settings
docs.text:
Basic application settings:

[hashreport]
# Hash algorithm and output settings
default_algorithm = "md5"
default_format = "csv"
supported_formats = ["csv", "json"]

# File processing settings
chunk_size = 4096
mmap_threshold = 10485760  # 10MB - Use mmap for files larger than this
timestamp_format = "%y%m%d-%H%M"
show_progress = true
max_errors_shown = 10

docs.title: Core Settings
docs.text:
• default_algorithm: Default hash algorithm to use (default: "md5")
  • default_format: Default output format (default: "csv")
  • supported_formats: List of supported output formats (default: ["csv", "json"])
  • chunk_size: Size of chunks for file reading in bytes (default: 4096)
  • mmap_threshold: Size threshold for memory-mapped files in bytes (default: 10485760)
  • timestamp_format: Format for timestamps in report filenames (default: "%y%m%d-%H%M")
  • show_progress: Show progress bar during processing (default: true)
  • max_errors_shown: Maximum number of errors to display (default: 10)

docs.title: Resource Management
docs.text:
Control system resource usage:

[hashreport]
# Resource monitoring settings
memory_threshold = 0.85  # % of total memory
min_workers = 2
max_workers = 0  # 0 = Use CPU count
worker_adjust_interval = 60  # seconds
memory_limit = 0  # 0 = 75% of total RAM
batch_size = 1000
max_retries = 3
retry_delay = 1.0
resource_check_interval = 1.0  # seconds
progress_update_interval = 0.1  # seconds

docs.title: Resource Settings
docs.text:
• memory_threshold: Memory usage threshold as percentage of total RAM (default: 0.85)
  • min_workers: Minimum number of worker threads (default: 2)
  • max_workers: Maximum number of worker threads (default: 0 - uses CPU count)
  • worker_adjust_interval: Interval for adjusting worker count in seconds (default: 60)
  • memory_limit: Memory limit in MB (default: 0 - uses 75% of total RAM)
  • batch_size: Number of files to process in each batch (default: 1000)
  • max_retries: Maximum number of retry attempts (default: 3)
  • retry_delay: Delay between retries in seconds (default: 1.0)
  • resource_check_interval: Interval for resource checks in seconds (default: 1.0)
  • progress_update_interval: Interval for progress updates in seconds (default: 0.1)

docs.title: File Processing
docs.text:
Configure file processing behavior:

[hashreport]
# File processing settings
min_file_size = "0B"
max_file_size = ""  # Empty string = No limit
default_recursive = true
ignore_hidden_files = true
ignore_system_files = true
excluded_directories = [".git", "__pycache__", "node_modules"]
excluded_extensions = [""]

docs.title: File Processing Settings
docs.text:
• min_file_size: Minimum file size to process (default: "0B")
  • max_file_size: Maximum file size to process (default: "" - no limit)
  • default_recursive: Process subdirectories by default (default: true)
  • ignore_hidden_files: Skip hidden files (default: true)
  • ignore_system_files: Skip system files (default: true)
  • excluded_directories: List of directories to exclude (default: [".git", "pycache", "node_modules"])
  • excluded_extensions: List of file extensions to exclude (default: [""])

docs.title: Email Settings
docs.text:
Configure email notification settings:

[hashreport.email_defaults]
port = 587
use_tls = true
host = "localhost"
timeout = 30
default_subject = "HashReport Results"
retry_attempts = 3

docs.title: Email Settings
docs.text:
• port: SMTP server port (default: 587)
  • use_tls: Use TLS for SMTP connection (default: true)
  • host: SMTP server hostname (default: "localhost")
  • timeout: SMTP connection timeout in seconds (default: 30)
  • default_subject: Default email subject (default: "HashReport Results")
  • retry_attempts: Number of email sending retry attempts (default: 3)

docs.title: Logging Settings
docs.text:
Configure logging behavior:

[hashreport.logging]
level = "INFO"
file_logging = false
log_directory = "logs"
max_log_size = "10MB"
backup_count = 5

docs.title: Logging Settings
docs.text:
• level: Logging level (default: "INFO")
  • file_logging: Enable file logging (default: false)
  • log_directory: Directory for log files (default: "logs")
  • max_log_size: Maximum size of log files (default: "10MB")
  • backup_count: Number of log file backups to keep (default: 5)

docs.title: Progress Display
docs.text:
Configure progress bar behavior:

[hashreport.progress]
refresh_rate = 0.1
show_eta = true
show_file_names = true
show_speed = true

docs.title: Progress Settings
docs.text:
• refresh_rate: Progress bar refresh rate in seconds (default: 0.1)
  • show_eta: Show estimated time remaining (default: true)
  • show_file_names: Show current file being processed (default: true)
  • show_speed: Show processing speed (default: true)

docs.title: Report Settings
docs.text:
Configure report generation:

[hashreport.reports]
include_metadata = true
include_timing = true
max_concurrent_writes = 4
compression = false

docs.title: Report Settings
docs.text:
• include_metadata: Include file metadata in reports (default: true)
  • include_timing: Include timing information in reports (default: true)
  • max_concurrent_writes: Maximum number of concurrent report writes (default: 4)
  • compression: Enable report compression (default: false)

docs.title: Contributing Guidelines
docs.text: Thank you for your interest in contributing to hashreport! This document provides guidelines and instructions for contributing to the project.

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text:
• Python 3.10 or higher
  • Git
  • Poetry (Python package manager)
  • Pre-commit hooks

docs.title: Setting Up the Development Environment
docs.text:
1. Clone the Repository 

    git clone https://github.com/madebyjake/hashreport.git
cd hashreport

  2. Install Poetry 

    curl -sSL https://install.python-poetry.org | python3 -

  3. Install Dependencies 

    poetry install

  4. Set Up Pre-commit Hooks 

    poetry run pre-commit install

  5. Verify Setup 

    poetry run pytest

docs.title: Running All Tests
docs.text:
# Run tests with coverage
poetry run pytest --cov=hashreport

# Run tests without coverage
poetry run pytest

# Run tests with verbose output
poetry run pytest -v

docs.title: Running Specific Tests
docs.text:
# Run a specific test file
poetry run pytest tests/test_scanner.py

# Run a specific test function
poetry run pytest tests/test_scanner.py::test_scan_directory

# Run tests matching a pattern
poetry run pytest -k "test_scan"

# Generate coverage report
poetry run pytest --cov=hashreport --cov-report=html

# View coverage in browser
open htmlcov/index.html

We use Black for code formatting:

# Format all Python files
poetry run black .

# Format a specific file
poetry run black hashreport/cli.py

docs.title: Linting

# Lint all Python files
poetry run flake8

# Lint a specific file
poetry run flake8 hashreport/cli.py

docs.title: Installation Methods
docs.text: There are two ways to install hashreport on your system. Choose the option that works best for you:

docs.title: Install with Pip
docs.text:
You can install hashreport using pip from the Python Package Index (PyPI). This is the recommended method for most users:

pip install hashreport

docs.title: 1. Download the Repository
docs.text:
Clone the repository to your local machine using Git and navigate to the project directory:

git clone https://github.com/madebyjake/hashreport.git && cd hashreport

Alternatively, you can download the repository as a ZIP file and extract it to a folder on your machine.

docs.title: 2. Install Dependencies
docs.text:
First we'll install Poetry, a Python packaging and dependency management tool. There are a few ways to do this, but the recommended method is to use the installer script:

curl -sSL https://install.python-poetry.org | python3 -

Next, install the project dependencies using Poetry:

poetry install

docs.title: 3. Run the Application
docs.text:
You can now run the application using Poetry:

poetry run hashreport --version

docs.title: Latest Version
docs.text:
# Upgrade to latest version
pip install --upgrade hashreport

docs.title: Specific Version
docs.text:
# Upgrade to specific version
pip install --upgrade hashreport==1.0.0

docs.title: Verification
docs.text:
After installation, verify that hashreport is working correctly:

# Check version
hashreport --version

# Run a test scan
hashreport scan --test /tmp

docs.title: Next Steps
docs.text:
After successful installation:

  1. Review the Quick Start Guide
  2. Learn about Basic Usage
  3. Explore Advanced Features
  4. Configure your Settings

docs.title: 1. Python Version Issues
docs.text:
If you see an error about Python version compatibility:

# Check your Python version
python3 --version

# If needed, install Python 3.10 or higher

## On Ubuntu/Debian:
sudo apt update && \
sudo apt install python3.10

## On Fedora/CentOS/RHEL:
sudo dnf update && \
sudo dnf install python3.10

## On macOS with Homebrew:
brew install python@3.10

docs.title: 2. Permission Issues
docs.text:
If you encounter permission errors:

# For pip installation
pip install --user hashreport

# For Poetry installation
poetry config virtualenvs.in-project true

docs.title: 3. Poetry Installation Issues
docs.text:
If Poetry installation fails:

# Try alternative installation method
python3 -m pip install poetry

# Or use pipx (recommended)
python3 -m pip install --user pipx
python3 -m pipx ensurepath
pipx install poetry

docs.title: 4. Virtual Environment Issues
docs.text:
If you have problems with virtual environments:

# Create a new virtual environment
python3 -m venv .venv

# Activate it
source .venv/bin/activate  # On Unix/macOS
.venv\Scripts\activate     # On Windows

# Install hashreport
pip install hashreport

docs.title: Getting Help
docs.text:
If you're still experiencing issues:

  1. Check the GitHub Issues for known problems
  2. Review the Troubleshooting Guide for more detailed solutions
  3. Create a new issue with:
  4. Your operating system and version
  5. Python version (python3 --version)
  6. Full error message
  7. Steps to reproduce the issue

docs.title: Project Scripts
docs.text: The scripts directory contains scripts that can be used for various common project actions. These scripts are intended to be run from the project root directory.

docs.title: Run Script
docs.text:
scripts/run.sh

The run.sh script is the main entry point for running project scripts, however, the scripts in the actions directory can also be run directly if desired.

docs.title: Options
docs.text:
The run.sh script provides a quick way to run various project actions. The following options are available:

  • -h, --help: show help message and exit
  • test: run tests with coverage
  • security: check for security issues
  • lint: lint the code
  • format: format code
  • install: install dependencies
  • setup-hooks: setup pre-commit hooks
  • pre-commit: run pre-commit hooks

docs.title: Interactive
docs.text:
The run.sh script can also be run in interactive mode. To do this, simply run the script without any options:

bash scripts/run.sh

This will prompt you to select an action to run.

docs.title: Non-Interactive
docs.text:
To run a specific action without being prompted, you can pass the action as an option:

bash scripts/run.sh [OPTION] [FLAGS]

For example, to run tests with coverage:

bash scripts/run.sh test

docs.title: Troubleshooting Guide
docs.text: This guide helps you resolve common issues with hashreport. If you're still experiencing problems, please check the GitHub Issues or create a new issue.

docs.title: Python Version Compatibility
docs.text:
Problem: Error about Python version compatibility Solution: Ensure you're using Python 3.10 or higher

# Check Python version
python3 --version

# Install Python 3.10 or higher on macOS
brew install python@3.10

# Install Python 3.10 or higher on Ubuntu/Debian
sudo apt install python3.10

# Install Python 3.10 or higher on Fedora/CentOS/RHEL
sudo dnf install python3.10

docs.title: Poetry Installation
docs.text:
Problem: Poetry installation fails Solution: Try alternative installation methods

# Install with pip
python3 -m pip install poetry

# Or use pipx (recommended)
python3 -m pip install --user pipx
python3 -m pipx ensurepath
pipx install poetry

docs.title: Permission Denied
docs.text:
Problem: Cannot access files or directories Solution: Check file permissions

# Check directory permissions
ls -la /path/to/directory

# Check file permissions
ls -la /path/to/file

# Fix permissions if needed
chmod 644 /path/to/file
chmod 755 /path/to/directory

docs.title: Path Issues
docs.text:
Problem: Invalid or inaccessible paths Solution: Verify path format and existence

# Use absolute paths
hashreport scan /absolute/path/to/directory

# Check path existence
ls /path/to/directory

# Handle spaces in paths
hashreport scan "/path/with spaces/directory"

docs.title: "File not found"
docs.text:
Solution: Verify file path and permissions 

ls -la /path/to/file

docs.title: "Invalid hash algorithm"
docs.text:
Solution: Check available algorithms 

hashreport algorithms

docs.title: Getting More Help
docs.text:
If you're still experiencing issues:

  1. Check Logs 

    # Enable debug logging
hashreport scan --debug /path/to/directory

  2. Create Issue

    You can create an issue on GitHub.

    Issues should include:

    • Any error messages
    • Any relevant logs
    • System information
    • Steps to reproduce
